options: A. Second brachial cleft anomaly
B. Third brachial cleft anomaly
C. Thyroglossal duct cyst
D. Cystic hygroma
E. Dermoid cyst

questions.question: A 7-year-old premenarchal female presents with left lower quadrant pain. On ultrasound, she is found to have a 7-cm complex cyst arising from her left ovary. What is the appropriate management for this cyst?
options: A. Close observation, with ultrasound every 6 months
B. Fenestration
C. Surgical excision of the cyst, leaving the left ovary in situ
D. Ten days of antibiotics
E. Reassurance since this is a normal finding

questions.question: An 8-year-old female presents as the restrained passenger after a head-on collision. On the secondary survey, a seatbelt sign is noted. In the pediatric population, what is an associated injury?
options: A. Chance fracture
B. Duodenal hematoma
C. Colonic perforation
D. Splenic hematoma
E. Hepatic hematoma

questions.question: Which of the following correctly describes a pulmonary sequestration?
options: A. Vascular connections are to the pulmonary artery and vein
B. Is a result of air trapping due to minimal expulsion of air with exhalation
C. Can be located both extralobar and intralobar
D. Communicates with the bronchial tree
E. Has minimal risk of infectious complications

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common congenital chest wall deformity?
options: A. Pectus carinatum
B. Poland’s syndrome
C. Convex chest wall deformity
D. Pigeon chest
E. Pectus excavatum

questions.question: Which of the following statements about omphalocele is false?
options: A. It is a midline congenital hernia of the abdominal viscera.
B. It is associated with other anomalies, particularly cardiac, in 50% of infants.
C. Immediate repair is an option for small omphaloceles.
D. A large omphalocele is managed nonoperatively in the newborn period to allow for slow closure over several months.
E. It is associated with a mortality rate of up to 40% with immediate primary closure.

questions.question: A newborn infant presents with a midline umbilical defect, through which a portion of the small bowel is protruding. The bowel appears pink and not dusky or edematous. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Umbilical hernia
B. Gastroschisis
C. Omphalocele
D. Urachal cyst
E. Umbilical granuloma

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about gastroschisis?
options: A. There is an absence of an umbilical cord in the fetus.
B. The defect is usually to the left of the midline.
C. An associated omphalocele is common.
D. Malrotation is always present.
E. It is a true hernia sac with peritoneum and skin.

questions.question: A newborn infant has a history of an umbilical cord defect. The infant is transferred to the operating room for repair. The small bowel is noted to be foreshortened, with a large-caliber bowel. What is the diagnosis?
options: A. Gastroschisis
B. Omphalocele
C. Umbilical hernia
D. Urachal cyst
E. Vitelline fistula

questions.question: Which of the following surgical procedures is the most appropriate for the management of the infant in Question 19?
options: A. Resection of the foreshortened bowel and end ileostomy
B. Primary closure of the abdominal wall defect
C. Staged closure of the abdominal wall defect with the use of a silo
D. Silon pouch with progressive closure
E. Silon pouch with resection of foreshortened bowel and delayed primary anastomosis

questions.question: Which of the following statements about omphalocele is true?
options: A. A major problem in the management of large omphaloceles is the limited size of the peritoneal cavity.
B. The abdomen of an infant with omphalocele is smaller than that of a newborn infant with gastroschisis.
C. Rupture of a sac is common in omphaloceles.
D. Omphalocele is less likely than gastroschisis to be associated with other congenital anomalies.
E. Omphalocele is a developmental malformation of the abdominal wall that occurs 1 to 2 cm lateral to the umbilicus.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about biliary cysts is true?
options: A. Type I choledochal cysts are rare.
B. Type I choledochal cysts have a risk for malignancy of less than 1%.
C. Type I choledochal cysts are saccular dilations of the entire biliary tree, with an associated risk of malignancy.
D. Type I choledochal cysts can be managed with a Roux-en-Y choledochoduodenostomy.
E. Type I choledochal cysts are primarily treated by internal drainage.

questions.question: Which of the following is true concerning Hirschsprung’s disease?
options: A. More common in females
B. Absent ganglion cells in both the Auerbach and Meissner plexuses
C. Failure to pass meconium in the first 72 h of life
D. Best diagnosed by lower-gastrointestinal (GI) contrast enhanced study
E. Atrophy of submucosal nerve endings seen in rectal biopsy specimens

questions.question: A newborn infant has failed to pass meconium by 48 h of life. The anus appears to be normally formed. An abdominal radiograph demonstrates dilated bowel loops with no air in the rectum. Which of the following tests is most likely to yield the diagnosis?
options: A. Upper GI study
B. Lower GI study
C. Suction rectal biopsy
D. Exploratory laparotomy
E. CT scan

questions.question: A previously well 3-week-old infant exhibits a sudden onset of bilious vomiting. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Pyloric stenosis
B. Duodenal atresia
C. Malrotation of the midgut
D. Intussusception
E. Tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), H type

questions.question: For the scenario described in Question 25, which would be the most appropriate initial diagnostic test?
options: A. Upper GI contrast study
B. Abdominal ultrasound
C. Barium enema
D. Abdominal radiograph
E. CT scan

questions.question: A 2-month-old otherwise healthy male presents with a 10-h history of bilious vomiting. An upper GI shows a corkscrew appearance of the duodenum that does not cross back over to the left side of the abdomen. Which of the following is correct regarding the management of this patient?
options: A. Orogastric tube should be placed, and the patient should have serial abdominal examinations over the next 24 h.
B. If intestinal volvulus is found at operation, the bowel should be rotated clockwise to reduce the volvulus.
C. Appendectomy should never be performed during surgery for this problem.
D. There is a high risk that this could recur even after surgery.
E. Surgery includes lysis of Ladd’s bands and positioning the duodenum along the right abdominal gutter.

questions.question: Which bowel segment is the most common site of intestinal duplication?
options: A. Esophagus
B. Stomach
C. Duodenum
D. Ileum
E. Rectum

questions.question: Which of the following is a criterion in the Alvarado scoring system for appendicitis?
options: A. C-reactive protein
B. Nausea and vomiting
C. Rovsing’s sign
D. Diffuse peritonitis
E. Sick contacts

questions.question: A 1-month-old neonate has an umbilical hernia with a palpable 1-cm defect. Which of the following statements is true?
options: A. The likelihood of spontaneous closure is low, and the hernia should be repaired.
B. Indications for the early repair of an umbilical hernia include a history of incarceration, a large skin proboscis, and the presence of a ventriculoperitoneal shunt.
C. Repair of the hernia defect should include the placement of a mesh.
D. Complete closure of the umbilical ring may be expected in 30% of children by the age of 4 to 6 years.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: The most common cause of duodenal obstruction at birth is:
options: A. Malrotation
B. Duodenal atresia
C. Annular pancreas
D. Choledochal cyst
E. Midgut volvulus

questions.question: A newborn infant presents with a radiograph shown in Fig. 31.2. What is the appropriate operative intervention?
options: A. Duodenojejunostomy
B. Duodenoduodenostomy
C. Gastrojejunostomy
D. Orogastric tube decompression alone
E. Ladd’s procedure

questions.question: A 5-year-old boy presents to your clinic for a complaint of a new onset of a palpable, firm mass in his right lower abdomen, extending into the flank. The mass is not tender. His physical examination is otherwise unremarkable. He has a history of an umbilical hernia repair as a newborn and has no family history of cancer. Which of the following statements is true regarding his likely diagnosis?
options: A. Surgical exploration and tumor resection with clear margins should be performed as a first step.
B. The prognosis is poor with a less than 20% 5-year survival rate.
C. He should be offered radiation therapy.
D. He should be offered a workup for a concurrent pancreatic cancer.
E. His likely diagnosis is neuroblastoma.

questions.question: A 4-year-old child presents to the emergency room with right upper quadrant pain that has progressed to his back. His mother states that a new mass was palpable in his right side. He has a fever of 101.4°F and is tachycardic to 134 bpm, and his blood pressure is 88/44 mmHg. He is intubated, and the ultrasound in the emergency department reveals a mass that is continuous with the liver but is separate from the gallbladder. The mass has no calcification and is partially cystic. What is the most appropriate next step in management?
options: A. CT abdomen/pelvis with IV contrast
B. Percutaneous drainage and antibiotics
C. Operative resection of the mass
D. Angiography and embolization
E. Liver transplant

questions.question: A 3-year-old female presents for a follow-up appointment with her parents. On her last visit she was diagnosed with an atrial septal defect. On this visit, she is diagnosed with a sacrococcygeal teratoma. Which of the following statements is true about this finding?
options: A. This mass is usually benign in males.
B. This mass is malignant in 10%–20% of patients.
C. The prognosis is best when surgical resection is performed at age 3.
D. Resection is the only treatment required for a malignant mass.
E. Adjuvant therapy is not an option for patients with sacrococcygeal teratoma.

questions.question: A 3-day-old infant is noted to have a defect in the right abdomen that contains herniated small bowel, stomach, and liver. The defect is to the right of the umbilical cord and appears to have a normal peritoneal sac. The patient is otherwise healthy, with no other congenital anomalies. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Gastroschisis
B. Omphalocele
C. Urachal cyst
D. Umbilical hernia
E. Vitelline fistula

questions.question: Which of the following congenital anomalies of the abdominal wall is more likely to have a synchronous malrotation of the intestine?
options: A. Omphalocele
B. Gastroschisis
C. Umbilical hernia
D. Vitelline fistula
E. Umbilical granuloma

questions.question: A 2-day-old infant presents with a bilious emesis and abdominal distention. The abdominal radiograph reveals a “double bubble” appearance. What is the most likely cause of this finding?
options: A. Pyloric stenosis
B. Duodenal atresia
C. Malrotation with midgut volvulus
D. Intussusception
E. Annular pancreas

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding congenital diaphragmatic hernia (CDH)?
options: A. It occurs as a result of a defect in the pleuroperitoneal membrane.
B. Most CDH are asymptomatic and are diagnosed in adults.
C. Most CDH involve the right side.
D. Most CDH have a sac.
E. It is associated with a high rate of recurrence after surgical repair.

questions.question: A 25-year-old woman is a candidate for elective surgery. She has a history of a tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF), H type. This is a common form of TEF, representing up to 80% of all cases. She has never undergone surgery for it, but she is followed with a routine flexible endoscopy of the esophagus and trachea for surveillance. Which of the following statements is true regarding her condition?
options: A. She can continue to eat and drink normally but should not drink while talking to avoid a cough.
B. The TEF should have been repaired at birth to prevent infection.
C. The TEF will spontaneously close after a few months.
D. She should be advised against pregnancy.
E. The TEF may be a contraindication to a surgical repair of an aortico-esophageal fistula that she may be at risk for with a vascular repair.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding Hirschsprung’s disease?
options: A. It is more common in males than in females.
B. It is most frequently a disease of the transverse colon.
C. It is diagnosed in the first 24 h of life in all patients.
D. It is a disease of the proximal colon.
E. It is a disease that can resolve spontaneously in a minority of children by the age of 5.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the management of esophageal atresia and tracheoesophageal fistula (TEF) in an infant?
options: A. The esophagus should be repaired first, followed by repair of the TEF.
B. The common type of TEF is the H type, and it is usually accompanied by esophageal atresia.
C. Surgery is never an option, and the patient is usually maintained with a gastrostomy tube.
D. The TEF is often repaired with a single ligation, and the esophagus is then anastomosed as a single layer.
E. The surgery is usually staged, with the initial step being repair of the TEF.

questions.question: A 10-month-old infant is being evaluated for a complaint of a large, firm, abdominal mass that crosses the midline. He has a complaint of fever and weight loss. Which is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Wilms tumor
B. Neuroblastoma
C. Mesenteric cyst
D. Rhabdomyosarcoma
E. Hepatoblastoma

questions.question: A 15-month-old presents with a large abdominal mass in the right abdomen. On examination, the mass is firm and mobile, and it crosses the midline. There are no other signs of metastases. Which of the following is true regarding the diagnosis of a Wilms tumor?
options: A. It has a male-to-female ratio of 2:1.
B. It has an association with congenital syndromes including trisomy 21.
C. It is typically associated with hypertension.
D. The rate of synchronous bilateral involvement is 50%.
E. On physical examination, it is usually palpable in the flank and does not cross the midline.

questions.question: Progressive abdominal distention and bilious vomiting develop in a newborn. Radiographic studies reveal distended bowel loops of various sizes with air-fluid levels and a “soap suds” appearance in the right lower quadrant. Which of the following procedures should be performed next?
options: A. Laparotomy
B. Paracentesis
C. Gastrografin lower GI radiographic studies
D. Gastrografin upper intestinal radiographic studies
E. Sweat chloride test

questions.question: A 13-month-old male presents to the emergency room with 13 h of colicky abdominal pain, emesis, a palpable sausage like abdominal mass, and blood-tinged stools. Which test is most appropriate to determine the diagnosis?
options: A. Plain radiograph
B. MRI
C. Upper GI
D. Ultrasound
E. Complete blood count with differential

questions.question: Select the true statement regarding the operative management of intussusception.
options: A. After successful reduction by barium enema, exploration is indicated to rule out the associated pathologic processes.
B. After successful reduction by barium enema in a 1-year-old child, delayed surgery should be performed because of the risk for recurrence.
C. If barium enema reduction is not successful, a resection should be performed without an attempt at intraoperative manual reduction, whether or not the bowel appears to be viable.
D. If resection is necessary, a primary ileocolic anastomosis may be performed.
E. Appendectomy should never be performed after successful operative manual reduction since this introduces an additional risk.

questions.question: Contraindications to attempted reduction of an intussuscep tion with a hydrostatic or barium enema in a child include which of the following?
options: A. Pneumoperitoneum
B. Presentation after 48 h of symptoms
C. Recurrence after prior hydrostatic reduction
D. Age older than 5 years
E. Recurrent symptoms in the immediate postreduction period

questions.question: A 13-month-old child is admitted to the hospital with lower GI bleeding. Which of the following is correct regarding the most common cause of lower GI bleeding in this patient?
options: A. Heterotopic pancreatic mucosa is likely to be the cause of bleeding.
B. The bleeding source is most commonly found on the mesenteric side of the intestine.
C. The most common location of the bleeding source is in the jejunum.
D. This problem is not likely to be confused with acute appendicitis.
E. It is a result of an incomplete closure of the omphalomes enteric duct.

questions.question: A 2-year-old boy is seen in your office with a midline neck mass that has been present for 2 months. On examination, the mass is 2 cm in size, is not tender or pulsatile, and moves with the protrusion of his tongue. Ultrasound of the neck demonstrates a midline cystic lesion sitting deep to the strap muscles with no surrounding lymphadenopathy or other pathology. The thyroid gland is noted in the normal location. Findings on thyroid function studies are normal. Which of the following statements is true regarding this mass?
options: A. Simple excision of the mass is sufficient.
B. This mass most likely represents ectopic thyroid tissue.
C. The rate of recurrence is very high after an appropriate therapy.
D. These lesions can be found along the base of the tongue and hyoid bone.
E. Most lesions are associated with a draining cutaneous fistula tract.

questions.question: Which of the following is false regarding the blood supply of skin grafts?
options: A. Full-thickness skin grafts (FTSGs) revascularize faster because they are transferred with their own blood supply.
B. FTSGs have a lower rate of scar contracture than split-thickness skin grafts (STSGs).
C. FTSGs contain sebaceous glands, hair follicles, and sweat glands, and therefore the cosmetic result is better.
D. STSGs may be meshed to cover a larger surface area.
E. Thinner STSGs have a better chance of survival than thicker grafts because they are less dependent on blood supply.

questions.question: All of the following are true regarding a TRAM flap for breast reconstruction except:
options: A. If the patient has adequate abdominal tissue, a TRAM flap is an excellent option and has the added benefit of a modified abdominoplasty.
B. A TRAM flap offers the benefit of increasing or decreas ing the volume accordingly if the patient gains or loses weight.
C. A disadvantage of the pedicle TRAM flap is the potential risk for abdominal hernias and abdominal wall laxity.
D. A latissimus dorsi myocutaneous flap is a reasonable option for this patient and has the benefit of avoiding abdominal donor site morbidity.
E. Deep inferior epigastric perforator flap is a reasonable option for this patient and has the benefit of avoiding abdominal donor site morbidity.

questions.question: When performing a component separation for a large abdominal wall defect, which of the following describes the location of the relaxing incision?
options: A. The aponeurosis of the internal abdominal oblique, at the linea semilunaris
B. The aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique, 1 to 2 cm lateral to the linea semilunaris
C. The anterior rectus sheath, 1 to 2 cm medial to the linea semilunaris
D. The aponeurosis of the internal abdominal oblique, 1 to 2 cm lateral to the linea semilunaris
E. The aponeurosis of the external abdominal oblique, 1 to 2 cm medial to the linea semilunaris

questions.question: Which of the following is inconsistent with the diagnosis of abdominal compartment syndrome?
options: A. Oliguria or anuria
B. Bladder pressures exceeding 20 to 25 mmHg
C. Peak airway pressures > 45 cmH2O
D. Intraabdominal pressure greater than 16 mmHg
E. Elevated central venous and pulmonary artery pressures

questions.question: Which of the following is a potential late complication of radiation therapy to the face?
options: A. Ectropion
B. Osteoradionecrosis
C. Loss of bone volume
D. Hypoxia
E. Telangiectasias

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about the anatomy of the skull?
options: A. The zygomatic arch is composed of the zygoma and the temporal bones.
B. The naso-orbital-ethmoidal (NOE) complex consists of the bilateral frontal processes, the maxilla, and the vomer bone.
C. The frontal sinus is the most common sinus to fracture.
D. The maxilla and zygoma bones are fixed into the skull by three horizontal and one vertical buttress.
E. The maxilla is not associated with the hard palate.

questions.question: A 24-year-old male presents with a depressed fracture of the right frontal sinus, and he denies any loss of consciousness, periorbital ecchymosis, or diplopia. He has no cerebrospinal fluid leak. There is no evidence of frontal sinus outflow obstruction. Which of the following is the most appropriate management?
options: A. Surgical repair of the posterior table and obliteration of the frontal sinus
B. Surgical repair of the posterior table and obliteration of the frontal sinus with removal of the frontal sinus mucosa
C. Open reduction and internal fixation of the anterior wall of the frontal sinus
D. Cranialization of the frontal sinus and removal of the posterior wall
E. Obliteration of the frontal sinus, removal of the posterior and anterior walls, and removal of the mucosa

questions.question: A 36-year-old male sustains a crush injury to his right hand and has a complete transection of the flexor pollicis longus at the level of the proximal phalanx. Which of the following statements is true regarding this injury?
options: A. This is in zone V, and immediate repair is warranted.
B. The primary repair of the flexor tendon within a “no man’s land” has a low rate of adhesion.
C. The goal of surgical repair is to perform a primary repair after a thorough debridement of the wound.
D. Tendon repair is not considered an option for patients with a prolonged ischemic time of the injured digit.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about hand anatomy is true?
options: A. The blood supply to the hand is primarily via the radial artery in 60% of people.
B. Injury to the median nerve leads to an inability to abduct the fingers.
C. Injury to the ulnar nerve at the elbow leads to loss of sensation in the median aspect of the hand.
D. The lumbricals originate from the extensor tendons.
E. The radial nerve innervates the extensor muscles of the fingers.

questions.question: A 40-year-old man who is a construction worker sustains a partial transection of the extensor pollicis longus at the level of the first metacarpal. What is the correct zone of injury?
options: A. Zone I
B. Zone III
C. Zone V
D. Zone VI
E. Zone VII

questions.question: A 32-year-old male presents with a deep laceration to his wrist from a knife. On examination, there is no motor or sensory function below the wrist. Which of the following statements is true regarding the patient’s condition?
options: A. The median nerve is most at risk for injury in this patient.
B. There is no risk of vascular injury as the major vessels are located deep to the tendons at the wrist.
C. Repair of the tendons is the most critical component of the repair.
D. Nerve repair should be prioritized before tendon and bone repair.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: A 23-year-old woman presents to the plastic surgeon’s office complaining of a mass behind her left ear. She is concerned that it is cancer. It has been present for a year and has not been increasing in size. On examination, a well-circumscribed, firm, mobile, and nontender mass is palpated behind the ear, consistent with a mass arising from the parotid gland. The mass does not move with mastication or with protrusion of the tongue. The most appropriate management is:
options: A. Simple excision of the mass with a frozen section
B. Total parotidectomy
C. Superficial parotidectomy with facial nerve dissection and preservation
D. Fine-needle aspiration
E. All of the above

questions.question: A 45-year-old female presents to the emergency room with a laceration on her right ring finger with a complete transection of the flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) tendon at the level of the distal interphalangeal (DIP) joint. Which of the following zones of injury is this?
options: A. Zone I
B. Zone II
C. Zone III
D. Zone IV
E. Zone V

questions.question: A patient is undergoing an exploratory laparotomy with an end-to-end anastomosis of a perforated small bowel from a gunshot wound. Which of the following best describes this type of wound?
options: A. Clean
B. Clean contaminated
C. Contaminated
D. Dirty
E. None of the above

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding wound dehiscence?
options: A. It occurs most often in the early postoperative period within the first 10 days of surgery.
B. The risk for wound dehiscence is increased with the use of chromic suture.
C. The overall rate of wound dehiscence is 20%.
D. The use of a retention suture for closure of the abdomen is associated with a lower rate of wound dehiscence.
E. It is usually preceded by a diagnosis of a surgical site infection.

questions.question: A 35-year-old woman is a candidate for breast reconstruction. She underwent a mastectomy with axillary dissection and radiation therapy for an adenocarcinoma of the breast. She has a history of an autoimmune disease that requires steroid treatment. Which of the following reconstruction options would be least appropriate for this patient?
options: A. Immediate breast reconstruction with a tissue expander
B. Delayed reconstruction with an implant
C. Delayed breast reconstruction with a latissimus dorsi myocutaneous flap
D. Delayed breast reconstruction with a free TRAM flap
E. TRAM flap reconstruction

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding tissue-sparing mastectomy and breast reconstruction?
options: A. Nipple-sparing mastectomy should not be performed in patients with invasive carcinoma.
B. The areolar region is spared and then biopsied during a nipple-sparing mastectomy.
C. Skin-sparing mastectomy is associated with a lower rate of local recurrence when compared with a traditional mastectomy.
D. Delayed reconstruction is associated with a shorter length of stay and fewer hospital visits.
E. None of the above.

questions.question: A 47-year-old man presents with a 2-cm defect in the posterior part of his leg that is the result of a motor vehicle crash. Which of the following is true regarding the initial management of this wound? A. The wound should be allowed to heal by secondary intention to prevent infection. B. The wound should be closed primarily, with the edges of the wound debrided back to healthy tissue. C. The wound should be managed with delayed primary closure. D. The wound should be closed immediately with a skin graft. E. The wound should be treated with topical antibiotics for 24 h and then closed primarily.
options: A. The wound should be allowed to heal by secondary intention to prevent infection.
B. The wound should be closed primarily, with the edges of the wound debrided back to healthy tissue.
C. The wound should be managed with delayed primary closure.
D. The wound should be closed immediately with a skin graft.
E. The wound should be treated with topical antibiotics for 24 h and then closed primarily.

questions.question: A 30-year-old woman who has had a mastectomy has an infected breast implant with purulent drainage coming out of her chest. What is the most appropriate management?
options: A. Immediate explantation of the implant and placement of a new tissue expander
B. Incision and drainage of the purulence with antibiotics
C. Incision and drainage of the purulence with antibiotics and placement of a new permanent implant
D. Implant salvage with antibiotics with or without a drainage procedure
E. Incision and drainage of the purulence with antibiotics and no implant replacement

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the reconstruction of a scalp defect is correct?
options: A. The blood supply is from the superficial temporal and occipital arteries.
B. Healing can only occur with a graft as there is no lymphatic drainage.
C. Small defects can be reconstructed with a split-thickness skin graft over the exposed bone.
D. Resection of the galea is necessary for reconstruction of a small defect.
E. The defect is best repaired with a flap of bone, periosteum, and skin.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding a midface fracture?
options: A. It can be caused by blunt trauma from a fall.
B. Naso-orbital-ethmoidal (NOE) fractures are best treated with observation if there are no signs of orbital entrapment.
C. Naso-orbital-ethmoidal (NOE) fractures should be treated within 1 week of injury to prevent enophthalmos.
D. Le Fort II fractures are pyramidal fractures of the midface involving the nasal bones, medial walls of the maxilla, inferior orbital rims, and palate.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most significant finding in a patient with a orbital fracture?
options: A. Enophthalmos
B. Ectropion
C. Diplopia
D. Air in the orbit
E. Exophthalmos

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding the anatomy of the skull?
options: A. The zygomatic arch is composed of the zygoma and the temporal bones.
B. The naso-orbital-ethmoidal (NOE) complex consists of the bilateral frontal processes, the maxilla, and the vomer bone.
C. The frontal sinus is the most common sinus to fracture.
D. The maxilla and zygoma bones are fixed into the skull by three horizontal and one vertical buttress.
E. The maxilla is not associated with the hard palate.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about fractures of the skull?
options: A. The mandible is the most common facial bone to be fractured.
B. Patients with a mandible fracture in two or more sites require a CT scan.
C. Nondisplaced fractures of the mandible can be treated with closed reduction and arch bars.
D. Midfacial fractures are always closed.
E. In a Le Fort I fracture, the maxilla is separated from the zygoma and the pterygoid plates.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male presents with a complete transection of the extensor pollicis longus at the level of the metacarpal. What is the correct zone of injury?
options: A. Zone I
B. Zone II
C. Zone III
D. Zone IV
E. Zone V

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding flexor tendon repair of the hand?
options: A. Both flexor digitorum profundus (FDP) and flexor digitorum superficialis (FDS) have to be repaired in all circumstances.
B. Repair of the tendons should occur within 24 hours of the injury to prevent adhesion formation.
C. A prolonged period of immobilization is required for the healing tendons.
D. Repair of a flexor tendon has a higher rate of adhesion formation than repair of extensor tendons.
E. The best site for flexor tendon repair is zone V (the carpal tunnel).

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding a crush injury to the hand?
options: A. Fractures can be pinned primarily with K-wires.
B. Amputation is a better option than replantation when the ischemic time exceeds 4 h.
C. The skin can be closed primarily if there is no excessive tension on the wound.
D. The goal of surgical intervention is to debride all devitalized tissue without compromising a functional limb.
E. Nerve repair should be prioritized before vascular repair.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding a replantation of an amputated hand?
options: A. The overall survival rate of a replanted hand exceeds 80%.
B. Early replantation has a lower risk for infection.
C. The likelihood of a complication from replantation is 5%.
D. The average length of stay following a replantation is 4 days.
E. All of the above.

chapters.title: Chapter 33: Special Considerations in Surgery: Pregnant, Geriatric, and Immunocompromised Patients

questions.question: A 32-year-old female who is 12 weeks pregnant presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, and right lower quadrant pain. She is admitted to the hospital, and a laparoscopic appendectomy is performed. What is true regarding the management of this patient?
options: A. In the late second trimester, the risk of miscarriage is increased from surgery.
B. The risk of fetal death is reduced if the patient can be kept in a supine position in the OR.
C. The risk of miscarriage is highest with the use of a Veress needle at the start of the operation.
D. The risk of fetal death is increased from operative trauma if the appendix is normal.
E. The patient must be intubated for the operation to prevent aspiration.

questions.question: A 23-year-old woman is a restrained passenger in a motor vehicle collision. Her primary survey is normal. A pregnancy test is positive, and the fetus is at 28 weeks’ gestation. She complains of abdominal pain. On physical examination, there is a uterine contraction every 5 min. What is the most appropriate next step in the management?
options: A. Placement of a nasogastric tube for decompression
B. Placement of an arterial line to monitor blood pressure
C. Admission to the hospital for fetal and uterine monitoring
D. Laparotomy for uterine bleeding
E. CT of the abdomen and pelvis to rule out placental abruption

questions.question: A 32-year-old female presents with fever, nausea, vomiting, and right lower quadrant pain. She is admitted to the hospital, and a laparoscopic appendectomy is performed. The uterus is at 22 weeks’ gestation. Which of the following statements regarding the surgery is true?
options: A. A low-pressure pneumoperitoneum of 10 mmHg should be maintained for the duration of the procedure.
B. The uterus must be manipulated to allow for adequate exposure to the abdomen.
C. The Hasson technique for abdominal access is contraindicated.
D. The left upper quadrant is a safe place for abdominal access in the early stages of pregnancy.
E. The operating table should be placed in a 30-degree Trendelenburg position.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about age-related changes in the elderly?
options: A. Cardiac reserve increases with age.
B. Renal function is not affected by age.
C. Immune function is not affected by age.
D. Pulmonary reserve increases with age.
E. Hepatic function is not significantly affected by age.

questions.question: Which of the following statements concerning anesthetic and medication administration in the elderly is true?
options: A. Plasma albumin levels decrease, which increases the proportion of protein-bound drugs.
B. The rate of drug metabolism of the liver decreases, which requires a decrease in the dose of medication.
C. Total body water increases with age, which decreases the concentration of water-soluble drugs.
D. The use of spinal anesthesia is contraindicated in the elderly.
E. None of the above.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true about surgical care in the elderly?
options: A. Surgical risk is determined solely by chronologic age.
B. Withholding of oral feeds in elderly patients after surgery is recommended to prevent aspiration.
C. Elderly patients are more susceptible to the development of hypothermia during the intraoperative period.
D. The ability to increase heart rate in response to stress increases with age.
E. The incidence of surgical site infections is not higher in the elderly compared with younger patients.

questions.question: A 75-year-old male with a history of hypertension, coronary artery disease with prior myocardial infarction (MI), and chronic renal insufficiency is undergoing a laparoscopic cholecystectomy. Which of the following is the most likely postoperative complication?
options: A. Atelectasis
B. Congestive heart failure
C. Arrhythmia
D. Wound infection
E. Renal failure

questions.question: An 80-year-old man undergoes a total thyroidectomy for papillary thyroid carcinoma. He is on multiple medications for hypertension, diabetes, and atrial fibrillation. The patient is found to have postoperative delirium. Which of the following medications is a potential cause of delirium?
options: A. Metoprolol
B. Propofol
C. Acetaminophen
D. Morphine
E. Nicardipine

questions.question: A 70-year-old female presents with a 2-cm mass in her right breast that is found to be an infiltrating ductal carcinoma. She is a surgical candidate for an open biopsy. She has multiple comorbidities. Which of the following statements is true regarding breast cancer in the elderly?
options: A. Hormonal therapy should not be given.
B. The prognosis for breast cancer in the elderly is worse than in a younger patient.
C. Elderly patients are less likely to have a hormonal-dependent tumor.
D. A modified radical mastectomy is the preferred surgical option.
E. Breast conservation therapy with radiation therapy, without axillary dissection, followed by hormonal therapy is a viable option.

questions.question: A 66-year-old woman with a history of breast cancer 10 years ago, treated with lumpectomy and radiation therapy, presents with a new abdominal mass. A biopsy of the mass is consistent with a mucinous adenocarcinoma. The patient has a new diagnosis of diabetes mellitus. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Colonic cancer
B. Pancreatic cancer
C. Metastatic breast cancer
D. Mucinous ovarian cancer
E. Gastric cancer

questions.question: A 23-year-old man who is a known carrier of a mutation in the CF transmembrane conductance regulator (CFTR) gene is admitted for an exacerbation of his disease. He has a complicated course and requires an ileocecectomy for an obstructing intestinal mass. Pathologic evaluation of the mass demonstrates a diagnosis of mucocele. What is the most likely underlying condition in this patient that is associated with an increased risk for malignancy?
options: A. He has an increased risk for appendiceal adenocarcinoma.
B. He has an increased risk for colorectal cancer.
C. He has an increased risk for lung cancer.
D. He has an increased risk for pancreatic cancer.
E. He has an increased risk for gastrointestinal stromal tumor.

questions.question: A 32-year-old woman with human immunodeficiency virus (HIV) infection and a CD4+  T-cell count of 50 cells/mL3, who has not been adherent with her antiretroviral regimen, undergoes a laparotomy for a perforated viscus. Which of the following statements is correct regarding this patient?
options: A. In the setting of a perforated viscus, a primary anastomosis is contraindicated.
B. In the setting of a perforated viscus and localized peritonitis, the patient will have normal findings on physical examination.
C. The diagnosis of perforated viscus in this patient would be straightforward, with classic findings on physical examination and imaging.
D. This patient is at an increased risk for a perirectal abscess that may lead to rectovaginal fistula.
E. The overall prognosis of this patient is determined solely by the surgical procedure performed.

questions.question: What are the common infectious causes of a perforated viscus in patients with HIV infection?
options: A. Mycobacterium avium-intracellulare
B. Cytomegalovirus
C. Cryptococcus
D. Kaposi sarcoma
E. All of the above

questions.question: With regard to the surgical management of patients with HIV, which of the following is true?
options: A. Surgical outcomes are similar to those of the general population in asymptomatic HIV-positive patients.
B. The overall surgical complication rate is 50%.
C. The operative mortality rate is 30% for all patients with HIV.
D. Surgical site infections occur 50% more often in asymptomatic HIV-positive patients than in the general population.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: A 56-year-old male with a history of neutropenia secondary to a recent chemotherapy regimen presents to the emergency room with a fever, lower abdominal pain, and bloody stools. A CT scan of the abdomen is obtained, which demonstrates diffuse cecal wall thickening. Which of the following is true regarding this patient’s condition?
options: A. The patient should be taken immediately to the operating room for a right hemicolectomy.
B. The diagnosis is most commonly attributed to an obstruction of the appendiceal orifice.
C. The patient should be treated with broad-spectrum antibiotics and nutritional support.
D. The patient should be treated with a right hemicolectomy if he becomes afebrile after 48 h of antibiotic therapy.
E. He has a higher risk for having a perforated duodenal ulcer.
E. He has a higher risk for having a perforated duodenal ulcer.

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman with long-standing end-stage renal disease who is being maintained on peritoneal dialysis (PD) has had several months of intermittent abdominal pain and difficulty obtaining normal dwell volumes for her peritoneal catheter. She goes to the emergency department because she was unable to adequately drain her peritoneal fluid. Review of her medical records reveals that her creatinine level has slowly been increasing for the last several months without any change in her dialysis regimen. Abdominal CT shows ascites; shortened, thickened small bowel mesentery; and diffusely thickened small bowel with areas of luminal narrowing. There are punctate calcifica tions throughout the peritoneum. Which of the following statements is true?
options: A. The patient has a bowel obstruction, and exploratory laparotomy is indicated.
B. The patient should have her PD catheter immediately exchanged for a new catheter.
C. The patient has an ongoing infectious process that is resistant to her antibiotics.
D. The patient most likely has encapsulating peritoneal sclerosis and should undergo surgery for enterolysis.
E. The patient most likely has encapsulating peritoneal sclerosis and should have her PD catheter removed and be switched to hemodialysis.

questions.question: Which of the following statements is least true about peritonitis in patients undergoing peritoneal dialysis (PD)?
options: A. It is most often caused by Staphylococcus species.
B. Fungal peritonitis is more common than bacterial peritonitis.
C. Broad-spectrum antibiotics are administered before culture results are known.
D. The fluid leukocyte count and differential count are useful for the diagnosis of infection.
E. There is a correlation between the duration of PD and the number of episodes of peritonitis.

questions.question: With regard to ascites in patients with cirrhosis, what is the best treatment option for a patient with refractory ascites and normal renal function?
options: A. Peritoneovenous shunt
B. Total parenteral nutrition
C. Transjugular intrahepatic portosystemic shunt (TIPS)
D. Peritoneal dialysis
E. All of the above.

questions.question: A 64-year-old man with end-stage renal disease is visiting from Mexico. He is evaluated in the emergency department for worsening vague abdominal pain, occasional vomiting, and abdominal swelling. The pain has been present intermit tently for several months but has worsened over the last few weeks. He has lost about 30 lbs. and has no appetite or energy. A purified protein derivative (PPD) skin test is positive, and the patient gives a history of being successfully treated for tuberculosis (TB) several years ago. Ultrasound shows moderate ascites with echogenic material within the fluid and no dilated bowel. What is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Lymphatic leak
B. Cirrhosis
C. Tuberculous peritonitis
D. Nephrotic syndrome
E. Pancreatic ascites

questions.question: With regard to peritonitis, which of the following statements is false?
options: A. A patient with a chronic history of peritoneal dialysis has a higher risk of peritonitis.
B. Chronic bacterial peritonitis is usually the result of a perforated viscus.
C. Tuberculous peritonitis is most often associated with patients with end-stage liver disease.
D. Tuberculous peritonitis should be suspected if a patient has a long history of abdominal pain with weight loss.
E. The diagnosis of tuberculous peritonitis can be made from a biopsy of the peritoneum.

questions.question: A 74-year-old man undergoes total laryngectomy for laryngeal cancer. He has a history of a coronary artery disease with a prior coronary artery bypass graft. He is 48 h out from surgery. Which of the following is true about his postoperative care?
options: A. It is a reasonable goal to extubate him immediately after surgery.
B. It is unnecessary to monitor the patient for a possible atrial fibrillation.
C. He should be started on a nasogastric tube feeding immediately after surgery.
D. His incision is considered a clean-contaminated wound.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding the aging process is true?
options: A. The number of nephrons decreases by 50% from age 30 to 80.
B. There is a decrease in myocardial contractility and stroke volume.
C. The sympathetic nervous system activity and the heart’s response to beta-adrenergic agonists decrease with age.
D. There is an increase in total lung capacity.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: Which of the following is true in regard to cardiac changes with age?
options: A. The response of the heart to a physiological stress is not attenuated with age.
B. With aging, the left ventricle becomes more compliant.
C. Increased peripheral vascular resistance is found in a geriatric patient.
D. The capacity to increase heart rate during exercise is not affected by age.
E. None of the above.

questions.question: Which of the following is true about the respiratory system in the elderly?
options: A. There is a 50% decrease in the vital capacity from the age of 30 to 70 years.
B. The most important predictor of postoperative pulmonary complications is a forced expiratory volume 1 (FEV1) > 2.0 L.
C. The elderly have a decreased ability to cough effectively.
D. The use of anesthesia has no effect on the elderly patient’s ventilatory capacity.
E. The most important predictor of pulmonary complica tions is a decreased forced vital capacity (FVC).
E. The most important predictor of pulmonary complica tions is a decreased forced vital capacity (FVC).

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor for the development of postoperative delirium?
options: A. Advanced age
B. Male gender
C. Preexisting cognitive impairment
D. Alcohol use
E. Sleep deprivation

questions.question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the management of delirium?
options: A. The primary method of prevention and treatment is the use of tranquilizers.
B. It is most frequently found in younger patients after a motor vehicle collision.
C. It is diagnosed using the confusion assessment method in the intensive care unit (CAM-ICU).
D. The use of propofol in the intensive care unit has no bearing on the incidence of delirium.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding chronic kidney disease?
options: A. It is often diagnosed with the presence of proteinuria in the urinalysis.
B. The overall rate of CKD is decreasing in the United States.
C. In the older population, the estimated glomerular filtration rate (eGFR) is a better indicator of renal function than serum creatinine.
D. It is characterized by the formation of simple renal cysts, which have a high malignant potential.
E. It is diagnosed by the presence of a serum creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL.
E. It is diagnosed by the presence of a serum creatinine > 2.0 mg/dL.

questions.question: Which of the following is a symptom of a patient with chronic renal disease?
options: A. Anemia
B. Hypocalcemia
C. Hypokalemia
D. Hypertension
E. All of the above

questions.question: Which of the following is true regarding medication dosing in patients with end-stage renal disease (ESRD)?
options: A. The dose of ampicillin needs to be adjusted in patients with ESRD.
B. All medications that are cleared by the kidneys are easily managed by decreasing the dose by 50% from normal.
C. Medications metabolized by the liver are not affected by the presence of ESRD.
D. Renal replacement therapy does not need to be considered in patients on PD.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: A 45-year-old male with a long history of substance abuse has been off his antiretroviral medications and presents with a perianal abscess. He is afebrile with a normal WBC count and no signs of sepsis. Which of the following is true regarding this patient’s condition?
options: A. A digital rectal examination is not necessary if the patient has no symptoms of perianal pain.
B. A perianal abscess in an immunocompromised patient should always be drained in the operating room.
C. Perianal abscesses in immunocompromised patients have the same microbiologic spectrum as in immunocompetent patients.
D. Perianal Crohn’s disease is a potential cause of his abscess.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: A 35-year-old female presents with fever, right lower quadrant pain, and leukocytosis. She has a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and is maintained on a daily dose of prednisone 10 mg. She is admitted to the hospital, and a laparoscopic appendectomy is performed. On day 3 postoperatively, she continues to have fevers. Her WBC count is 17,000 cells/mm3, with a normal differential. Which of the following is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Surgical site infection
B. Postoperative ileus
C. Acute lung injury
D. Anastomotic leak
E. Viral infection

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman with chronic renal failure on hemodialysis presents to the emergency room with a fever of 103°F. She is currently undergoing evaluation for a renal transplant. Her history includes an appendectomy as a child. Her abdomen is soft, nondistended, and nontender. Lab results are significant for a WBC count of 12,000 cells/mm3, and there is no evidence of a left shift. The dialysis catheter has no erythema or purulence. Which of the following is not a common infectious etiology for her fever?
options: A. Dialysis access infection
B. Urinary tract infection
C. Pneumonia
D. Clostridium difficile colitis
E. All of the above are common infectious etiologies in this patient.

questions.question: A 23-year-old male with a history of leukemia is in the hospital after a recent chemotherapy. He is neutropenic with a WBC count of 500 cells/mm3. He presents with a fever, abdominal distention, and diarrhea. CT scan shows cecal wall thickening. What is the most appropriate management for his neutropenic colitis (typhlitis)?
options: A. Surgical exploration is indicated immediately.
B. The mortality rate from nonoperative management is greater than 80%.
C. G-CSF should not be used.
D. Surgical management is indicated for free perforation, persistent GI bleeding, or persistent fever despite 5 days of antibiotic therapy.
E. All of the above.

questions.question: A 62-year-old woman with long-standing end-stage renal disease who is being maintained on peritoneal dialysis (PD) has had several months of intermittent abdominal pain and difficulty obtaining normal dwell volumes for her peritoneal catheter. She goes to the emergency department because she was unable to adequately drain her peritoneal fluid. Review of her medical records reveals that her creatinine level has slowly been increasing for the last several months without any change in her dialysis regimen. Abdominal CT shows ascites; shortened, thickened small bowel mesentery; and diffusely thickened small bowel with areas of luminal narrowing. There are punctate calcifica tions throughout the peritoneum. Which of the following is least appropriate?
options: A. Trial of tamoxifen therapy
B. Oral steroid pulse
C. Replacement of the PD catheter
D. Immunosuppressive therapy with azathioprine
E. Exploratory laparoscopy and enterolysis

questions.question: A 54-year-old woman with end-stage renal disease treated by PD complains of abdominal pain and fever. When perform ing her exchanges she has noted turbid fluid for the last several days. She has been undergoing PD for 3 years and has never had any complications. Which of the following statements is correct?
options: A. She should undergo immediate peritoneal exploration with removal of the dialysis catheter.
B. Fungal peritonitis requires long-term antifungal therapy through the PD catheter.
C. PD-associated peritonitis from coagulase-negative staphylococci can be cured with antibiotics alone in more than 80% of cases.
D. She will need to resume hemodialysis while the infection is treated.
E. Broad-spectrum empirical antibiotic therapy is required because peritoneal fluid cultures have little value.

questions.question: A 76-year-old man with cardiac, liver, and renal disease is admitted to the intensive care unit with fever, hypotension, and abdominal distention. An abdominal ultrasound reveals ascites. His serum albumin level is 2.8 g/dL, and the albumin concentration in the ascites fluid is 3.6 g/dL. This serum ascites albumin gradient (SAAG) is most supportive of which of the following diagnoses?
options: A. Lymphatic leak
B. Cirrhosis
C. Tuberculous peritonitis
D. Nephrotic syndrome
E. Pancreatic ascites

questions.question: A 64-year-old man with end-stage renal disease is visiting from Mexico. He is evaluated in the emergency department for worsening vague abdominal pain, occasional vomiting, and abdominal swelling. The pain has been present intermit tently for several months but has worsened over the last few weeks. He has lost about 30 lbs. and has no appetite or energy. A purified protein derivative (PPD) skin test is positive, and the patient gives a history of being successfully treated for tuberculosis (TB) several years ago. Ultrasound shows moderate ascites with echogenic material within the fluid and no dilated bowel. Which of the following tests would be most helpful in making a diagnosis?
options: A. CT of the abdomen and pelvis
B. Percutaneous peritoneal biopsy
C. Microscopic examination of peritoneal fluid
D. Mycobacterial cultures of peritoneal fluid
E. Diagnostic laparoscopy and peritoneal biopsy

questions.question: A 48-year-old man underwent human leukocyte antigen (HLA)–matched allogeneic bone marrow transplantation for myelofibrosis with myeloid metaplasia. One month after discharge, he returned to the clinic with a 2-week history of anorexia, malaise, low-grade fevers, and difficulty swallow ing. His tongue was chalky white. Esophagogastroduodenos copy revealed white plaques throughout the esophagus, and colonoscopy showed linear, well-demarcated ulcers in the terminal ileum and cecum. He was prescribed oral nystatin and treated for his neutropenia. Two days later, severe abdominal pain develops, and CT shows a perforation at the distal ileum. Which of the following is the most likely cause of the ileal perforation?
options: A. Epstein-Barr virus (EBV)
B. Cytomegalovirus (CMV)
C. Cryptococcus
D. Candida albicans
E. Herpes simplex virus

questions.question: Which of the following should not be included in the initial approach to a profoundly neutropenic patient with fever?
options: A. Skin, mucous membrane, and ophthalmoscopic examination
B. Inspection and cultures from central venous access
C. Digital rectal examination
D. Chest radiograph
E. Initiation of empirical antibiotic therapy

questions.question: A 39-year-old HIV-positive man who is noncompliant with his antiretroviral medications wishes a second opinion because of 1 month of progressive abdominal pain, diarrhea, low-grade fever, and malaise. He has a history of Pneumo cystis carinii pneumonia. At initial presentation, his abdomi nal CT showed thickening of the terminal ileum with a small amount of surrounding fluid. Colonoscopy showed circumfer ential ulcers and inflamed mucosa; biopsy of the cecum and terminal ileum showed granulomas. Therefore a diagnosis of Crohn’s disease was made, and the patient was treated with steroids. However, 1 month later his symptoms are worse, and repeated CT shows increased cecal and peritoneal thickening, ascites, and large mesenteric lymph nodes with hypodense centers. Suspecting that the initial diagnosis may have been in error, which of the following conditions is the most likely diagnosis?
options: A. Crohn’s disease
B. Cecal carcinoma
C. Tuberculous enteritis
D. Intestinal amebiasis
E. Small bowel lymphoma

questions.question: Which of the following strategies is least useful for improv ing surgical outcomes in geriatric patients?
options: A. Preoperative evaluation of medical physiologic status
B. Optimization of physical and cognitive function
C. Minimization of perioperative nutritional deficiency
D. Postoperative assessment for rehabilitation options
E. Surgical risk assessment based on a specific diagnosis

questions.question: Regarding the following several scenarios, which one of the operations can proceed as scheduled?
options: A. An 80-year-old scheduled for cataract surgery who has a pulse of 60 beats/min and a blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg and is completely asymptomatic
B. A 67-year-old scheduled for left total hip arthroplasty who has a pulse of 80 beats/min and blood pressure of 180/110 mmHg, is asymptomatic, and takes metoprolol

C. A 65-year-old hypertensive scheduled for bilateral total knee arthroplasty who has a pulse of 94 beats/ min and a blood pressure of 104/68 mmHg and who takes an angiotensin-converting enzyme (ACE) inhibitor
D. An 80-year-old scheduled for bilateral laparoscopic hernia repair who has a pulse of 42 beats/min and a blood pressure of 100/60 mm Hg and who has a pacemaker and takes metoprolol
E. None of these operations should proceed

questions.question: A 73-year-old man undergoes open cholecystectomy. His return of gastrointestinal function is delayed, so he has a nasogastric tube for 2 days. On postoperative day 4, he has fever, productive cough, and an infiltrate on chest x-ray. Which of the following is true?
options: A. The risk of aspiration in an 80-year-old is nearly double that of a 25-year-old patient.
B. Prolonged nasogastric suction eliminates the risk for aspiration pneumonia.
C. Older patients with dementia or delirium are at increased risk for aspiration.
D. The use of anesthesia has no effect on the elderly patient’s ventilatory capacity.
E. The incidence of aspiration pneumonia actually decreases with increasing age because the immune response to chemical pneumonitis is less vigorous.

questions.question: Which of the following is incorrect when comparing geriatric patients with younger patients?
options: A. Elderly patients have lower creatinine values.
B. The risk for hypothermia is greater in elderly patients.
C. Fever is a less reliable sign of infection in elderly patients.
D. Colon pathology is the most common indication for surgery in elderly patients.
E. Cardiac complications are the leading cause of perioperative complications in the elderly.

questions.question: Following cholecystectomy, an 82-year-old patient has an oxygen saturation of 88% on 2 L of oxygen by nasal cannula. Which of the following is not a probable explanation for this phenomenon?
options: A. Maximal breathing capacity is 50% of what the patient had at age 30.
B. The cough mechanism is less effective in elderly patients.
C. The pulse oximetry reading is spurious.
D. The patient was recently repositioned from supine to a sitting position.
E. The patient required conversion from laparoscopic to open cholecystectomy.

questions.question: Which of the following statements regarding age-related changes in the cardiovascular system is not correct?
options: A. Ventricular contractility decreases
B. Sympathetic nervous system activity decreases
C. Mean arterial pressure increases
D. Left ventricular afterload increases
E. Myocardial contraction is prolonged

questions.question: A 74-year-old man is admitted for cardiac surgery. His preopera tive creatinine level is 1.6 mg/dL. Which of the following statements about renal function in elderly patients is correct?
options: A. Renal blood flow decreases by up to 20% from baseline by the age of 80.
B. Loss of renal mass is most pronounced in the renal medulla.
C. Nephron hypertrophy compensates for the loss of nephrons with age.
D. Simple renal cysts in older patients are frequently malignant.
E. Serum creatinine is usually elevated because of decreased glomerular filtration rate.

questions.question: Which of the following is correct when assessing the clinical impact of age-related changes in renal function?
options: A. Medication dosing should be based on serum creatinine rather than eGFR.
B. A decrease in the ability of the kidney to conserve chloride results in a predisposition to dehydration.
C. Most urinary tract infections are symptomatic.
D. Susceptibility to acute kidney injury (AKI) is about the same in older patients because of a decrease in lean body mass.
E. The response to increases in serum osmolarity is blunted in older adults.

questions.question: A 36-year-old female with a history of systemic lupus erythematosus and has been on 10 mg of prednisone daily for the past 6 months is in the emergency room with right lower quadrant pain and is found to have appendicitis. She is taken to the OR for a laparoscopic appendectomy. At the conclusion of the case, what is the best way to manage her pain?
options: A. Morphine delivered by PCA
B. Patient-controlled anesthesia with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug (NSAID)
C. Patient-controlled anesthesia with a nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drug and morphine
D. Epidural anesthesia with a combination of a local anesthetic and a small amount of opiate
E. She has undergone a simple laparoscopic procedure and will not need significant pain control.

questions.question: Which of the following is a risk factor for a patient with Crohn’s disease to have a complicated postoperative course?
options: A. The patient’s age
B. The patient’s nutritional status
C. The use of steroids in the 6 weeks prior to surgery
D. A patient with fistulizing disease
E. All of the above.

chapters.title: Chapter 34: Evidence-Based Surgery and Applications of Biostatistics

questions.question: As part of an effort to reduce the length of hospital stay, right hemicolectomy patients were placed on a clinical pathway. All of the first seven patients placed on the pathway did well except the last patient, in whom aspiration pneumonia developed and necessitated 1 month in the intensive care unit. The lengths of stay for these patients were 3, 4, 4, 5, 6, 7, and 41 days. What are the mean, median, and mode of the length-of-stay data?
options: A. Mean = 10, median = 5, mode = 4
B. Mean = 5, median = 10, mode = 5
C. Mean = 10, median = 4, mode = 1
D. Mean = 10, median = 5, mode = 41
E. Mean = 5, median = 5, mode = 1

questions.question: A patient is at postoperative day 5 from an open cholecys tectomy and has a prolonged ileus. You are attempting to use the pain scales to titrate down his pain medication dosage. Which of the following data types (i.e., nominal, ordinal, interval, and ratio) correctly describe the variables (i.e., gender, respiratory rate, pain scale, and date of month)?
options: A. Nominal, Ordinal, Interval, Ratio
B. Nominal, Ratio, Ordinal, Interval
C. Interval, Ratio, Ordinal, Nominal
D. Ordinal, Interval, Ratio, Nominal
E. Nominal, Interval, Ordinal, Ratio

questions.question: A fourth-year resident is attempting to determine where his American Board of Surgery In-Training Examination score falls nationally. He is given a histogram and the standard deviation (SD). Which of the following is true about descriptive statistics?
options: A. A histogram graphically depicts the means of experimen tal observations from a population.
B. A skewed distribution will be highly symmetrical.
C. For a normal distribution, 95% of data points will fall within 1 SD of the mean.
D. Mean, median, and mode are all approximately the same for a normal (Gaussian) distribution.
E. The 50th percentile of any data set is equivalent to the mean.

questions.question: Which of the following is true?
options: A. Variance is the sum of the absolute differences between each sample point and the mean.
B. The sample SD will be small if the sample size is large.
C. The standard error of the mean (SEM) is independent of the sample size.
D. SEM can be obtained by dividing the sample SD by the square of the sample size (N2).
E. SD is better than SEM for describing scatter in the data.

questions.question: While attempting to research whether an excisional biopsy or a stereotactic core-needle biopsy is more effective at obtaining a tissue diagnosis in breast cancer, you find that the odds ratio of a true positive cancer diagnosis with a core needle biopsy is 0.95 [95% confidence interval (CI), 0.92–10.8]. Which of the following is correct about descrip tions and estimations of populations?
options: A. The 95% reference range will contain all of the data 95% of the time.
B. To calculate a 95% CI, the sample must contain 95% of the population.
C. Nonparametric statistics are most useful if the population distribution is normal and the sample size is large.
D. The 95% CI of the mean becomes smaller as the disper sion of the data decreases or the sample size increases.
E. The number of degrees of freedom is inversely propor tional to the sample size.

questions.question: Seventy-five surgical residents are surveyed to determine whether overnight calls have an impact on their driving habits. The relative risk (RR) of having a traffic accident in the month after an overnight call is calculated to be 1.0 [95% confidence interval (CI), 0.7–2.1]. Which of the following is the correct interpretation of the RR and CI?
options: A. There is no difference in risk between the two groups.
B. The risk is reduced in the group with the risk factor.
C. The risk is increased in the group with the risk factor.
D. The result is statistically significant and clinically significant.
E. More information is needed to determine the statistical significance of the results.

questions.question: A meta-analysis is being performed to determine whether a surgical intervention is more effective than a nonsurgical intervention. All of the studies, aside from one small study, showed no significant difference between the two interventions. The odds ratio of the treatment is 0.8 with a 95% CI of 0.7 to 1.1. Which of the following is the correct interpretation of the odds ratio and CI?
options: A. The results are significant because the odds ratio is less than 1.0.
B. The results are significant because the range of the CI is very narrow.
C. The results are not significant because the CI crosses 1.0.
D. The results are not significant because the CI crosses 0.0.
E. The results are not significant because the CI is between 0.0 and 1.0.

questions.question: In a prospective study, 100 patients with a known risk factor are followed to determine the outcome. In the control group, 200 patients without the risk factor are followed. The rate of the outcome in the group with the risk factor is 20%, whereas the rate in the control group is 10%. What is the RR of the outcome with the risk factor?
For the study described in Question 8, which of the following is the NNT to eliminate one episode of the outcome?

When determining how to compare the quality of life after diagnosis between stages of lung cancer, you decide to use nonparametric statistics. Which of the following is true about nonparametric statistics?
options: A. They have greater power than the corresponding parametric tests.
B. They require fewer assumptions about the form of the population from which the data are obtained.
C. They are generally more sensitive to outliers.
D. They are usually less robust than corresponding paramet ric statistics.
E. One example is the unpaired t test.

questions.question: A study is performed to assess the impact of weight loss surgery on diabetes. A total of 64 obese, diabetic patients undergo gastric bypass. Glycosylated hemoglobin (HbA1c) is measured for each patient 2 months before and 6 months after the surgery. For patients before surgery, the mean and SD of HbA1c were 9.2 and 2.1, respectively. After surgery, the corresponding values were 6.8 and 1.9, respectively. Which test would be most appropriate for comparing the two samples?
options: A. Unpaired t test
B. Paired t test
C. One-way analysis of variance (ANOVA)
D. Mann-Whitney U test
E. McNemar test

questions.question: Many of the obese diabetic patients also had gastroesophageal reflux disease (GERD). The investigators decided to assess whether gastric bypass surgery decreased the incidence of GERD. Before surgery, 46 (of 64) patients reported GERD. After surgery, only 32 patients reported GERD symptoms. What test would be most appropriate for determining whether the decrease in GERD was caused by chance?
options: A. Unpaired t test
B. Paired t test
C. One-way ANOVA
D. Mann-Whitney U test
E. McNemar test

questions.question: Which of the following is true about regression and correlation?
options: A. The dependent variable is used to predict the independent variable.
B. Multiple regression generally refers to more than one outcome variable.
C. In logistic regression, the outcome variable is categorical.
D. Two variables are uncorrelated if they have a negative correlation coefficient.
E. Correlation usually implies causation.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most effective method for reducing the influence of confounding variables in an interventional study?
options: A. Blinding
B. Randomization
C. The placebo effect
D. Subgroup analysis
E. All of the above

questions.question: A large study finds that patients who undergo a new operation for obesity lose 50 kg in the first year with a standard deviation (SD) of 5 kg. The sample mean and SD are used to calculate a reference range for the average weight loss. Which of the following is true about the reference range?
options: A. The range will be approximately from 40 to 60 kg.
B. The range will be approximately from 45 to 55 kg.
C. The range is a measure of a sample’s variability.
D. The reference range contains 95% of the values of the entire population from which the sample was obtained.
E. A and D.

questions.question: You find that the RR for having an anastomotic leak in patients with a concurrent enterotomy during a ventral hernia repair is 2.5. Which of the following is the correct interpretation of the RR?
options: A. The risk of having a leak in the enterotomy group is 2.5 times higher than that in the nonenterotomy group.
B. The risk of having a leak in the enterotomy group is 25 times higher than that in the nonenterotomy group.
C. The risk of having a leak in the nonenterotomy group is 2.5 times higher than that in the enterotomy group.
D. The risk of having a leak is increased by 25% with the enterotomy.
E. The risk of having a leak in the enterotomy group is 2.5%.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about confounding variables is true?
options: A. Confounding variables are equally associated with both the risk factor and the outcome.
B. The effects of confounding variables are more easily eliminated in observational studies than in interventional studies.
C. Confounding variables can be eliminated with a large sample size.
D. There is a strong association between the confounding variable and the risk factor.
E. There is a strong association between the confounding variable and the outcome.

questions.question: You are attempting to determine the odds of having a history of tobacco use in patients with pancreatic cancer. You decide to compare all patients with pancreatic cancer, smokers and nonsmokers, with healthy controls. Which of the following is true regarding observational (case-control or cohort) studies?
options: A. Patients with the disease of interest are randomized into treatment and nontreatment groups.
B. Case-control studies should not be used when a single disease has multiple causes.
C. Case-control studies are useful for assessing temporal relationships between causative agents and disease.
D. Incidence and RR can be measured directly in cohort studies.
E. Cohort studies are most useful for commonly occurring exposures and diseases.

questions.question: You are developing a prospective randomized control trial to establish the noninferiority of nonoperative treatment of appendicitis. Which of the following is true about interventional studies (randomized controlled trials)?
options: A. Randomization and large sample size generally reduce the effects of confounding variables.
B. Randomization serves to eliminate observational bias.
C. The effects of poor compliance with therapy can be eliminated with an “intention-to-treat” design.
D. Interventional studies are usually cheaper than observa tional studies such as case-control studies.
E. Randomized controlled trials are less subject to ethics concerns than are observational studies.

questions.question: A researcher decides to perform a meta-analysis to determine the best form of induction immunosuppression for living related-donor kidney transplantation. Which of the following is true with regard to meta-analysis?
options: A. Meta-analysis techniques cannot increase the power of an investigation.
B. Meta-analysis methods can eliminate observational or selection bias.
C. Many of the statistical techniques used in the meta-analy sis are unique to it.
D. Meta-analysis can be used to assess effect sizes and CIs.
E. “File drawer” or publication bias refers to the overinclu sion of studies supporting the null hypothesis.

questions.question: A study is initiated to determine whether the preoperative administration of an antibody directed against vascular endothelial growth factor increases the disease-free survival in patients with colon cancer treated by segmental colon resection. Which of the following is correct?
options: A. Survival analysis can be used only if the end point is death of the patient.
B. If a subject dies during a follow-up, the case is consid ered “censored.”
C. The hazard function represents the probability of a subject surviving a given length of time.
D. The Kaplan-Meier estimator can be used to compare two survival curves.
E. The Cox proportional hazards model allows examination of covariates underlying the survival curves.

questions.question: Which of the following represents the most effective evidence for screening or treatment modalities?
options: A. Randomized controlled trial
B. Controlled trial without randomization
C. Multicenter case-control study
D. Uncontrolled trial with dramatic results
E. Expert committee recommendations

questions.question: A patient with colon cancer wishes to enroll in a study of a new chemotherapeutic agent. Which of the following is not an essential element of informed consent?
options: A. A description of any risks or discomfort that the subject may experience
B. A review of alternative courses of treatment
C. A description of the methods for keeping the subject’s medical records private
D. Disclosure of the financial support for the study
E. A statement that participation in the study is voluntary

chapters.title: Chapter 35: Core Competencies and Quality Improvement

questions.question: How many core competencies emerged from the Accredita tion Council for Graduate Medical Education (ACGME) Outcomes Project?
Which of the following specific statements is part of the patient care core competency requirement?
options: A. Set learning and improvement goals
B. Incorporate formative evaluation feedback into daily practice
C. Demonstrate manual dexterity appropriate for the resident’s level
D. Participate in the education of patients and families
E. Communicate effectively with patients, families, and the public

questions.question: The ACGME medical knowledge core competency involves participation in an educational program that details the fundamentals of basic science as applied to clinical surgery. Topics include (1) wound healing; (2) homeostasis; (3) shock and circulatory physiology; (4) hematologic disorders; (5) immunobiology and transplantation; (6) oncology; (7) surgical endocrinology; (8) surgical nutrition and fluid and electrolyte balance; (9) metabolic response to injury, including burns, and: A. Bioinformatics and information systems in health care systems B. Wound closure techniques C. Principles of cardiac surgery D. Applied surgical anatomy and surgical pathology E. Technical aspects of a cholecystectomy
options: A. Bioinformatics and information systems in health care systems
B. Wound closure techniques
C. Principles of cardiac surgery
D. Applied surgical anatomy and surgical pathology
E. Technical aspects of a cholecystectomy

questions.question: Residents are expected to develop certain skills and habits so that they can meet all of the following goals to satisfy the patient care core competency requirement except:
options: A. Communicate effectively with patients, families, and the public
B. Demonstrate manual dexterity appropriate for the resident’s level of training
C. Develop and execute patient care plans appropriate for the resident’s level
D. Participate in a program that must document a clinical curriculum that is sequential, comprehensive, and organized from basic to complex

questions.question: Which of the following goals is considered a patient care core competency skill?
options: A. Set and improve learning goals.
B. Critically evaluate and demonstrate the knowledge of pertinent scientific information.
C. Demonstrate skills in the education of patients and families.
D. Act as an effective member of a health care team.
E. Manage a practice, including an understanding of cost-effective health care.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about professionalism is false?
options: A. Professionalism encompasses the relationship that physicians have with patients.
B. Integrity and empathy are two of the elements of professionalism.
C. Professionalism requires sensitivity to a diverse patient population.
D. Professionalism is not a core competency.
E. Residents are expected to practice medicine with honesty and integrity.

questions.question: Which of the following is a component of the medical knowledge core competency?
options: A. Critically evaluate a surgical procedure.
B. Develop and execute a patient care plan.
C. Teach in a classroom setting.
D. Provide medical care to all patients, regardless of their socioeconomic status.
E. Know the fundamentals of patient care.

questions.question: Which of the following statements about the core competencies is false?
options: A. A single activity can fulfill more than one competency.
B. Quality improvement is a component of systems-based practice.
C. Teaching to nurses and medical students can fulfill a practice-based learning and improvement core competency.
D. Professionalism is an underlying concept for all of the core competencies.
E. The core competencies are used to evaluate residents’ technical skills only.

questions.question: Which of the following is not a risk factor that predicts the occurrence of a surgical site infection (SSI)?
options: A. Patient factors, such as age and weight
B. Tumor factors, such as size and location
C. Preoperative factors, such as smoking, alcohol abuse, and uncontrolled diabetes
D. Intraoperative factors, such as duration of the surgical procedure and contamination of the wound
E. The surgeon’s level of skill

questions.question: A team approach to health care is the primary focus of: A. The medical knowledge core competency B. The practice-based learning and improvement core competency C. The interpersonal and communication skills core competency D. The systems-based practice core competency E. All of the above
options: A. The medical knowledge core competency
B. The practice-based learning and improvement core competency
C. The interpersonal and communication skills core competency
D. The systems-based practice core competency
E. All of the above

questions.question: A hospital is trying to improve the quality of care delivered to patients with a history of acute myocardial infarction. It assembles a multidisciplinary team to assess the use of medication in these patients. Which of the following is not an appropriate action to perform when improving a system?
options: A. Identify the problem within the system.
B. Develop a new system based on the underlying causes of the original problem.
C. Test the new system on a subset of the affected patient population.
D. Evaluate all available options before a solution is chosen.
E. Implement the new system on all patients.

questions.question: Which of the following is considered a surgical patient safety issue?
options: A. Patient identification and surgical site marking
B. Performance of a preoperative time-out
C. Use of a preoperative checklist
D. Readmission rates
E. All of the above
